definition: Zhao Kuangyin, personal name of founding Song emperor Song Taizu 宋太祖 (927-976)
surname Zhao/one of the seven states during the Warring States Period (476-220 BC)/the Former Zhao 前趙 (304-329) and Later Zhao 後趙 (319-350), states of the Sixteen Kingdoms
to surpass (old)
surname Kuang
to rectify
descendant/heir/offspring/posterity/to inherit

sentences.english: Although he was a military general, he was fond of reading.
sentences.chinese: 趙匡胤雖是一員武將，卻很喜愛讀書，常手不釋卷。

sentences.english: After the death of Zhao Kuangyin, his brother ascends the throne.
sentences.chinese: 趙匡胤死後，趙光義即位。

sentences.english: Zhao Kuangyin, accepting the demised throne of the Latter Zhough, founded the Song Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 趙匡胤接受了後周“禪讓”的帝位，建立宋朝。

definition: ancient official title
posthumous edict (of former emperor)
Later Zhou of the Five Dynasties (951-960), centered on Shandong and Hebei, with capital at Kaifeng 开封
to confer a title upon sb/to dub/to crown/to invest with rank or title
Emperor Xuan (91-48 BC) of the Former Han Dynasty, reigned 74-48 BC
arsenal/store of arms
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
to plot a rebellion/to conspire against the state
Zhu Qizhen, personal name of sixth and eighth Ming emperor Zhengtong 正統|正统[Zheng4 tong3], afterwards Tianshun Emperor 天順|天顺[Tian1 shun4] (1427-1464), reigned 1435-1449 and 1457-1464
to present tribute (to the emperor)
Emperor Yang of Sui (569-618), said to have murdered his father and brother to seize the throne, reigned 604-618
Kou Zhun (961-1023), Northern Song politician and poet
Emperor Xian of Han (181-234), the final Han emperor, set up by Dong Zhuo 董卓, reigned 189-220, forced to abdicate 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕
first Sui emperor (541-604) Yang Jian (541-604), reigned 581-604
Liu Yuan, warlord at the end of the Western Jin dynasty 西晋, founder of Cheng Han of the Sixteen Kingdoms 成漢|成汉 (304-347)
to ascend the throne
